name: Urinary Tract Infection - Classification and Management
content:
URINARY TRACT INFECTION (UTI):

CLASSIFICATION:

1. UNCOMPLICATED CYSTITIS:
   - Non-pregnant, premenopausal women
   - No structural/functional abnormalities
   - Symptoms: Dysuria, frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain
   - No fever or systemic symptoms

2. COMPLICATED UTI:
   - Male sex, pregnancy, immunosuppression
   - Structural/functional abnormalities (stones, catheter)
   - Healthcare-associated
   - Recent antibiotic use or resistant organisms

3. PYELONEPHRITIS:
   - Upper tract infection
   - Fever, flank pain, CVA tenderness
   - Nausea/vomiting
   - May have lower tract symptoms

4. ASYMPTOMATIC BACTERIURIA:
   - Positive culture without symptoms
   - Treatment only in pregnancy or before urologic procedures

DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA:

Uncomplicated cystitis:
- Symptoms alone sufficient in young women
- Urinalysis: Pyuria, bacteriuria, + nitrites, + leukocyte esterase
- Culture not routinely needed

Complicated UTI/Pyelonephritis:
- Urinalysis and urine culture
- Culture >10^5 CFU/mL (or >10^3 if catheterized)
- Blood cultures if septic
- Imaging (ultrasound, CT) if complicated course

COMMON PATHOGENS:
- E. coli (75-95%)
- Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterococcus
- Staphylococcus saprophyticus (young women)
- Pseudomonas (catheter-associated)

TREATMENT:

Uncomplicated Cystitis (3-5 days):
- First-line: Nitrofurantoin 100mg BID × 5 days
- Alternative: TMP-SMX DS BID × 3 days (if local resistance <20%)
- Second-line: Fosfomycin 3g single dose, Beta-lactams

Complicated UTI (7-14 days):
- Fluoroquinolone (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin)
- Ceftriaxone if severe
- Tailor based on culture results

Pyelonephritis:
- Outpatient (mild): Fluoroquinolone × 7 days or ceftriaxone 1g IV then oral
- Inpatient (moderate-severe): Ceftriaxone or fluoroquinolone IV
- Duration: 10-14 days total

Catheter-Associated UTI (CAUTI):
- Remove or replace catheter if possible
- 7-day treatment if prompt resolution
- 10-14 days if delayed response

PREVENTION:
- Adequate hydration
- Post-coital voiding (women)
- Avoid spermicides
- Cranberry products (limited evidence)
- Prophylaxis if recurrent (≥2 UTIs in 6mo or ≥3 in 12mo)
